insights: It's wonderful that you're looking to improve - focusing on understanding challenging concepts through extra tutoring or online tutorials can make a big difference in mastering chemistry.
Joining a study group can offer new perspectives and techniques for learning, making difficult topics more accessible and less overwhelming.
Consistently practicing with past exam questions can boost your confidence and help you identify areas where you need more review, turning weaknesses into strengths.
Remember, progress takes time and perseverance; celebrate small victories along the way to stay motivated and focused on your goal of entering a pharmacy course.
summary: Year 1 student. Reflected on course uncertainty and motivation this semester, Semester 2.
transcript:
Mirae: Hi! I'm glad you want to talk. I see you're in Year 1, Semester 2.
How are you doing this semester?
Student: Not very good. I almost failed my chemistry. How will that affect my possibility of getting in to pharmacy course in university, I'm very worried 
Mirae: It's completely normal to feel worried, especially when it comes to your future. One low grade won't define your entire academic journey, and there are still many opportunities to improve. Have you considered reaching out for extra help in chemistry or finding study groups? It might really boost your understanding and confidence! What do you think could help you feel more prepared for next time?
Student: How can i do better to salvage my grade
Mirae: You’re already taking a great step by wanting to improve! I suggest reaching out to your teacher for extra help or resources, and consider joining a study group with classmates. Practicing past exams or using online resources can also really help. What areas in chemistry do you find most challenging?
